qas.question: What do plants do when the environment makes fertilization especially difficult?

answers.text: replacing sexual reproduction with asexual reproduction

qas.question: How different are the children produced by asexual parents?
What is the term for asexual cloning?
Does apomixis only occur in the parent?

answers.text: can also happen in a seed

context: Unlike in higher animals, where parthenogenesis is rare, asexual reproduction may occur in plants by several different mechanisms. The formation of stem tubers in potato is one example. Particularly in arctic or alpine habitats, where <a0_0>opportunities for fertilisation of flowers by animals are rare<a0_0/>, plantlets or bulbs, may develop instead of flowers, <a1_0>replacing sexual reproduction with asexual reproduction<a1_0/> and giving rise to clonal populations <a2_0>genetically identical to the parent<a2_0/>. This is one of several types of apomixis that occur in plants. <a3_0>Apomixis<a3_0/> <a4_0>can also happen in a seed<a4_0/>, producing a seed that contains an embryo genetically identical to the parent.
